author: {'steamid': '76561198068635046', 'num_games_owned': 202, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 1376, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1255, 'last_played': 1523053808}
review:
Let's first lay out my experience with this game. I was accepted into the beta within the few weeks of development, and played when I got the chance from either university work, or other games. Being in the beta I saw first hand how responsive the devs were and how much they were actually communicating, and how easy it was to tell them something directly or ask a question. So take my word as you will, I may have a little bias, but from my point of view, the devs are working hard and they do NOT seem like the type trying to do a money grab. They are just 3 guys working their asses off trying to make the game as best they can. Onto the review.

The game is buggy, crashes, and really needs to be ironed out. Personally in my opinion release should've been delayed a little more, but deadlines are deadlines and they delayed release already. 

However, the game is still pretty fun, has good depth and a lot of potential. To anyone that thinks the game is just a shallow aoe2 clone, have not looked past the facts that the game has the same 4 resources, and a lot of the same themes and core rts ideas. The similarities kind of end there. The game is faster paced, the civs are (much) lower in quantity but made much more unique. To any 4X fans, think of the difference between civ 5 BNW vs Endless Legend. In Endless Legend there is only now 11 factions (not counting mezari who are a re-skin) compared to the 43 civilizations in civ 5 BNW. However, in civ 5 all the civs are basically the same, aside from unique minor bonuses and 2 unique units or 1 unique unit and a unique building/tile. However, in Endless Legend each faction is incredibly unique with access to different technologies, passive bonuses and debuffs, completely unique units, and play style. One faction litterally does not use food resources and instead uses dust (gold/currency) to create population and just prefers desert territories. Another faction has the ability to force peace/alliance with any other player and stop wars whenever they want, except with the one faction that when they declare war, its PERMANENT war (they instead enter a truce for a certain number of turns). The differences and uniqueness of the different factions/civs in Endless Legend make the differences in Civ 5 civs negligable, and not feel that impactful. Their isn't much difference between playing French or China. And it's the same in Empires Apart.

You have 6 civs currently.
-Byzantians, a civ that has STRONG infantry and revolves around a stun on hit mechanic. They also have strong siege and and different ways to access increasing efficiencies of villagers through the mill, or their priests that give auras that buff gather rates. 

-French, a civ that has decent towers and strong cavalry and want to take the game late to get their t3 heavy cavalry unit, the Paladins. Their units, however, have good strength throughout the game because their cavalry has  a charge mechanic that gives them (splash) damage to the first hit after moving for long times (building momentum). Their priests give a blessing buff to units.

-Chinese, a defensive and slightly more complicated civ with strong archers and kung fu warriror monks for priests. The monks can also be utilized for their healing aura while stationary as it can be used to heal villagers under the Overseer effect which increases gathering amounts in exchange for damaging the villager units. They also have flamethrowers and other shnanigans.

-Arabs, probably the latest civ in the game. They have decent upgrades to everything all around, and have naft throwers, an aoe ranged unit that are very useful. Universities allow the ability to have strong stats on all units if used correctly. They also have special assassin units, that are invisble, can break invisiblity when a certain distance from enemies, and when they break the invisiblity will have temporary "i-frames" and their next attack will kill the target and if will cause an aoe slow around the area. 

-Aztecs, an early game rush civ that focus on early map control and aggression. Instead of their units upgrading through buildings and spending resources for global unit promotions, units have experience and gain promotions from engaging in combat. This lets Aztes to have high promotion units very early, which they need as they have no cavalry or siege so they need that early aggression win. They are also able to capture enemy units instead of killing them and sacrafice them for bonuses, and their priests are capable of applying an aoe curse that slows enemies.

-Mongols, the other early game rush civ. Unlike the Aztecs that have 0 cavalry, all mongol units outside of villagers are mounted. They also have special units that transform into their buildings instead of building them, and this lets them disassemble buildings and move them into new spots that allows mongols to be nomadic in nature. They have the smallest tech tree but make up for it with early game activity and aggression. Very easy and fun civ to play. 

This uniqueness in civs allows for interesting play and interactions and depth (something that other reviews seem to say this game lacks). This game has it's rough edges, lots of it honestly. But the game is fun and has heart, and the devs really want to make a good game. Most of the bad decisions (price, launch date) were most likely the publishers, so if this game is screwed more likely their fault than the devs. But the game has potential and I think If people get the game and support the game it can grow into something beautiful.

However, I am not going to tell you to buy this game. This game is overpriced, has issues, and not a good release. I recommened this game to whoever is willing to take a bet on the game, otherwise I won't try and decieve you into purchasing a product that I probably would have looked over in dissapointment if I were not in the beta, no matter how short it was. That's all I have to say about this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198016750171', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 88, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 88, 'last_played': 1522396698}
review: I tried to get in on the beta for this and was denied several times. Decided what the heck and bought the game when it became available on steam, which after about 87 minutes I requested a refund for. Maybe after some updates the game will polished enough to be worth the 30 dollar price tag but tbh In it's current state I'd maybe pay between 10 and 15 dollars. I hate to be that guy but right now Age of empires 2 HD is far superior to this in just about every way, and with new RTS games on the horizon (Age 4, Iron Harvest, Stronghold 4.. etc) unless this game is updated or discounted it will be left behind.

author: {'steamid': '76561198012821311', 'num_games_owned': 509, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 317, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 87, 'last_played': 1547925188}
review: When it works properly it's a very good if basic RTS, but it rarely works for me. Every map play either end up with fatal errors and crashes or I get 9 fps on every graphics settings. The way I feel, this is just a early access game without the label.
developer_response:
Hi!

Unfortunately some people had low FPS issues at launch. Yesterday we released a patch which should greatly improve the situation.

Would you consider giving another try to the game and if you like it maybe reconsidering your review?

review:
The Game Has Potential Like Real ''Potential''
 It has fps issues
 It has few but good looking factions every faction has unique units (atleast the looks of it) more factions like Norse/Turks/Italians/British/Indians/Japanese/Spanish/Russians/Polish/Scottish/Germans Etc.(germans Could Have Like Teutonic Knights Like The French Having Templier Unit) Could Be Good
Few maps but new ones could be great
Challenges Are Enjoyable But Few But More Factions Could Do The Thing For This One Too
Beside The Challenges An ''Real'' Campaign would be great
And FPS Issues (sadly) :(

But I Think You Guys Can Handle Those :)
And I Will Wait For The See The Game Improve :)

author: {'steamid': '76561198029874230', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 172, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 71, 'last_played': 1522578999}
review:
Unfortunately a disappointment.

Reviewing Skirmish option
1)	Game rules on any game are:
a.	Game Mode (4 options)
b.	Map (7 different map styles)
c.	Map size (4 options)
d.	Pop cap (3 options)
e.	Visibility (3 option)

In my opinion is this is even less than basic. I miss a lot of options that are possible in almost all RTS games. 

2)	I can‚Äôt really see the difference between villagers and military men and I don‚Äôt have bad eyes. 
3)	I miss a lot of in game options.
a.	Your allies are always the same color (no options to disable this)
b.	No option to see how many villagers are on a particular job
c.	No in game score option
d.	Can‚Äôt see what you need for next age (only when you already reached the target)

4)	Movement and fighting of military men is really chaotic.
5)	The AI is really bad‚Ä¶. on hard they only target villagers, therefore they are easy to defeat. 
6)	The AI is really bad‚Ä¶ I build a wall with a gate and the enemy just walked back and forth, with the opening and closing of the gate (with the gate on automatic), until they died, without even attacking anything. That was the moment I quitted.

author: {'steamid': '76561198119361417', 'num_games_owned': 72, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 1575, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 881, 'last_played': 1605156662}
review: I love this game, its good fun especially for those of you who loved the old age of empires. However, there are things than need ironing out. For example the Mongols, they are my favorite civ but i feel like their cavalry is a little underwhelming, especially agaisnt top tier French and Arabic cav. I think the Mongol cav as a whole might need some tweaking to make them a bit more powerful. there are also a few glitches and the AI can be dodgy. but if you can get past these you will have a great time with this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561197989084563', 'num_games_owned': 572, 'num_reviews': 31, 'playtime_forever': 971, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 245, 'last_played': 1528549847}
review: I think this is a fantastic game thus far.  It needs more content -- more map variations, a campaign, and better AI.  The AI is definitely the worst part of the game, but there's so much that they got right.  The races are more different than in AoE2, the map is easy to read at a glance (minimap and playing field) and even though this isn't my style of graphics, it looks good.  The sound effects are a little weak, but that's not a major concern.  I would definitely recommend this to anyone that is a fan of classic RTS -- it really does capture almost all of the fun of the olden tymes.

author: {'steamid': '76561198078208697', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 89, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 89, 'last_played': 1522508016}
review:
Ich hab mich sehr gefreut, dass endlich wieder einmal ein AoE-√§hnliches Spiel rauskommt - und dies auch nicht als EA Titel. Allerdings hatte ich anfangs aufgrund der Desynchronisation das Problem, dass ich nicht online mit meinem Freund spielen konnte. Dann haben wir uns gedacht ok, warten wir ein bisschen. Dies wurde nun gefixt, allerdings hat er nun trotz eines starken PCs FPS Schwierigkeiten. Obwohl wir ein Spiel frisch starten und noch nicht einmal viele Einheiten und Geb√§ude und auch nur mit 2-3 KIs gespielt hatten, kam er maximal auf 10 FPS - sprich unspielbar. Wenn er ein Spiel er√∂ffnet, fliege ich auch einfach raus und wenn ich mich nochmals verbinden m√∂chte, kommt wieder die Desynchronisation und es tut sich nichts mehr. Auch bleibt es oft einfach nur h√§ngen, sodass ich es nur √ºber den Taskmanager schlie√üen kann. Und wie ihr sehen k√∂nnt, habe ich noch nicht einmal 2 Spielstunden und trotzdem diese Probleme in so kurzer Zeit. 

Das Spiel hat f√ºr mich somit einen EA Status. Auch was die Einstellungen angeht, ist es meiner Meinung nach ein EA Game (zB keine LAN M√∂glichkeit, bei Multiplayer Lobby kann man kein privates Game einstellen, es gibt sehr wenig Karten, Tiere buggen im Kreis rum usw). Der Aktionspreis 23 Euro statt 28 ist zwar nicht so viel, allerdings erwartet man sich viel mehr von einem Spiel, welches nicht im EA Status erschienen ist. 

Somit kann ich es zur Zeit nicht empfehlen!

review: El juego es estupendo. Todo lo que esperaba de √©l. Un m√°s que digno sucesor de la saga Age of Empires. La m√∫sica es sobresaliente. Los peque√±os fallos de la IA y el pathfinding que ten√≠a la beta (por algo era beta) han sido mejorados. El multijugador lo mejor. Divertid√≠simo. ¬°Lo recomiendo!

author: {'steamid': '76561198036075706', 'num_games_owned': 207, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 3983, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1906, 'last_played': 1660985211}
review:
I literary have been waiting for something similar to appear for at least ten years. I cannot understand many of the negative reviews that game has got , especially it is only out since two days. But most of those proably do not understand what major disappoitments  for example Empire Earth III, Planetary Anihilation and Dawn of war III have been. 

So far I have played it is solid and engageing at least for me.

It is played so far like AoE II but has an even faster speed ( I am used to 6+ hour marathons ine Empire Earth /3+ in AoE since there building material will be long gone/)
The differences between the empires are major while the classic rock paper scissors mechanic is still in play.
But the build order for the nations varies greatly.

There will be a lot which has to be edited and added but I think that I have to get the word out that it is good.

author: {'steamid': '76561198054398948', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 171, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 130, 'last_played': 1522992354}
review:
I will admit it is a bit difficult to recommend the game in its current state with a $30 price tag. And especially if you are not the kind of person that enjoys multiplayer and likes to queue up against AIs and nothing else, this is DEFINTELY not the game for you at all.
However, if you enjoy multiplayer, quick in-depth gameplay, and a ranked experience that doesn't require hours of Lobby Simulator 2018, then this is a title you can probably get a good deal of enjoyment out of.

All that said, from a game design perspective this game does a great job in my mind. It borrows and builds upon the old-school RTS model quite well-- although its choice of time period easily lends it to the "ripoff" label that I do not think it fully deserves. Functionally however, the game is missing a number of quality-of-life features and a level of polish that one might come to expect in an RTS. But as much as I resent the strategy of releasing games seemingly unfinished-- the developers seem very committed to improving the game. (For instance a balance/bug patch was pushed almost immediately after release when imbalance/desyncs were discovered.)

Subjectively I think the art style is quite nice and not nearly as distracting as many make it out to be, though many of the models are still far from perfect in my opinion.

Everything taken into consideration along with the commitment the small 3 man development team is showing toward the community's concerns, I'd say EA has a good potential for a strong future.

author: {'steamid': '76561198070723910', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 5062, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3457, 'last_played': 1582927948}
review:
Empires Apart is an indie title made by a small team, it is heavily inspired by Age of Empires 2 in units and theming, it's really good at what it does and an amazing amount of fun. I've never been much of a multiplayer person, but this title had me hooked since I entered beta. A few things are good to note about the design:

The pacing was designed to be fast without loss of strategic depth, which means streamlined. Most matches can be finished in 20-30 minutes. There is very little dead space or PvE (player versus environment) play at the start of a match, and not even beginners should feel like they need to jump through hoops with set build orders and such or like they'd rather play with rules like "no attacking for the first hour". Everything from gather rates and resource balance to map size and the availability of units and more town centers is very well tought out for what style of game Empires Apart wants to be. The scout can scan the environment in two long strokes, then scout the enemy or lure boar. Every task you think of is streamlined and quick, no chores that keep you from playing the rest of the game for half a minute. And when I said "no loss of strategic debt" up there I meant it. For optimal play you need to decide within the first two or three villagers you make whether you're emphasizing rush or boom, and start working towards the first big military or economy upgrade.

Empires apart was designed from the ground up to be intuitive. For instance: the anti-cavalry bonus is called "long weapon", and that's how you visually recognize all the units that have it. That bonus works on all mounted units. And now you know what you needed to know about that. If you can gather infantry in a building, you can gather cavalry there, if you can hand in fish at a dock you can hand in berries and wood and gold, no matter who or what killed an animal you can gather food from it. The game was made as intuitive as possible to pick up and start to play, even for those new to the genre.

Traditionally there are two ways to make a balanced multiplayer game: having two, three or maybe four completely unique civs, or having as many civs as you like that are very similar. Empires Apart embraces the age of patches to allow a degree of civ/faction uniqueness in between those two, dunking us into unexplored territory and some awesome matchups. This means that the game will keep getting balance patches for the forseeable future, since this kind of balance is inherently really hard to get right.

Empires apart was designed with all the conveniences of a modern RTS. Automatic farm reseeding, command queue, a clever control group system that allows you to run unit production quickly in between other tasks, ranked play on a ladder with matchmaking function, good HUD/UI. There is very little about this game to get frustrated about (other than an opponent who's playing just that little bit better than you of course).

Lesser sides: The single player options are bells and whistles. Fun, but not nearly as fun as the multiplayer. The short single player challenges are pretty good at teaching you the few tricks you won't pick up by yourself though, and complement the intuitive gameplay. The AI is aimed mostly at beginners, although it's scheduled to keep improving. The balance as mentioned before is not optimal yet. Plus the game has heroes. They're wel done and fit the rest of the game, but I'm just not a fan of heroes in general.

Overall though it's just a really fun title where you can jump into an all out war and be done in time for dinner. The great easily outweighs the "meh".

author: {'steamid': '76561197995311943', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 53, 'playtime_forever': 85, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 85, 'last_played': 1521004519}
review: tl;dr Empires Apart is a spiritual successor to Age of Empires: with no singleplayer content and a predictable, cliched multiplayer experience, and it's difficult to recommend Empires Apart at its price point. If you are an absolute die-hard RTS and Age of Empires fan, pick this game up, but anybody else should get it during a heavy sale.

author: {'steamid': '76561198048101201', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 200, 'playtime_forever': 312, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 261, 'last_played': 1526703616}
review:
This is a game that takes the Age of Empires gameplay we know and love and builds on it in small but fun and thoughtful ways. It's incredibly refreshing to see an RTS made that isn't trying to recapture the MOBA audience, and it's even more heartening to see the clear love for old-school RTS gameplay the developers are working from. In the early days after launch there have been issues - some serious performance problems on large maps and some occasional pathfinding goofs - but I'm already really enjoying the game as I'm able to play it, and the developers seem active and are working towards improving it; they've already released a few small patches that fixed one or two issues I was seeing.

There are tons of small conveniences in the UI that feel like they were designed by people who played and thought about AoE2 - markets and farms are handled much more elegantly, there's a button for grabbing your wounded units, there are better visualizations of control groups and idle villagers... a lot of small changes have been made to the familiar formula with the goal of improving quality of life, and for the most part it's been great!

The biggest difference between this and an old Age game is how unique each of the civilizations are. I've mostly been playing as Aztecs and Chinese so far, and each civ has unique mechanics and tech trees and units that make them feel like properly different experiences. I love the Aztec prisoner-taking mechanic in particular - there's a special fun to raiding your enemy, turning their units into prisoners, then converting the prisoners into free villagers or sacrificing them for resources. The way Mongols build and deconstruct and move their buildings around is actually really clever, and fun to play around with.

The art style is also fun and charming in its own way, even though there are a few uneven elements to it, and the sounds and music and voices are surprisingly well-done and nicely tailored to each civilization, considering this is very much a small, low-budget project.

No, I don't love every design choice - I think walls could stand to be more imaginative, I'm lukewarm on the day/night cycle, and a few of the units look a bit too similar to one another at a glance. But this is a valiant effort that has resulted in a fun game, and I want to see development continued and maybe even expanded upon. It could be something truly special, especially if it sees enough success for the devs to keep working on it for months or years to come.

That's why I'm rather unusually reviewing the game before I've really had my fill of it - traditional RTS games are an endangered species, and since I've really enjoyed my first few games (I was definitely worried it would be too janky before I actually played it), I wanted to throw a good review out there early to encourage people to try it and to encourage the devs to keep working on it. Once I've played all of the civs and modes more extensively, and once it's been patched a bit, I'll try to remember to update this review with some more precise thoughts.

author: {'steamid': '76561198004815718', 'num_games_owned': 323, 'num_reviews': 32, 'playtime_forever': 1069, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 962, 'last_played': 1546223711}
review:
Game is very solid. Some pros:

* The presentation is fantastic. UI, music and graphics are really polished. There are some caveats, for instance some units look very similar to each other so they could use some polish, and some UI elements are in odd places or have odd symbols so they need to be polished as well.
* Performance on my machine is fantastic, no surprises there. 
* Skirmish mode and challenge modes work well. The AI is relatively challenging at the harder levels and everything works as expected.
* Multiplayer is really snappy and I've had no issues with lag. Extremely hard against some players however. It looks like people have already figured out ways to cheese other players in 1v1 matches such as stealing your sheep and instantly killing them so their food goes to waste.

The game shipped at launch with (six? civs), plenty of single player modes and four multiplayer modes. No campaign but I mean, they never said they were gonna make that..? So idk why people are complaining.

Cons:

* The basic unit management AI needs some work. I've left some forum posts regarding some changes that need to be made to make the AI more intuitive.
* In general, all of the AI needs work. The enemy is pretty easy to steamroll and kite and usually they waste a lot of units by sending small amounts of units constantly to the enemy base. They also waste a lot of resources by building town centers at the enemy base and then not cancelling them so it becomes easy to cheese them in the late game.

I really enjoy the game, I think it needs some polish but for the most part I'd say it's a very successful release. Way better than the shit fest that was Grey Goo. Good job DESTINYbit.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025571627', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 1297, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 410, 'last_played': 1564984543}
review:
This game is one of the most interesting and beautiful ideas I have seen in a long time. The potential for this title is amazing and I hope that the developers are able to bring it to where it needs to be. 

But in all likely hood it will never get there.

Many People have complained about the single player, but the games focus says it is competitive multiplayer, so I will be discussing on that and tell you why I can‚Äôt recommend this amazing game.

Its relatively simple, there are 3 problems that will prevent this game from getting off the ground.

1) First it released in a very poor state (not in early access) which turned many people off from the game and stalled the player base, if you play a 2v2 and it gets to late game the game will crash. Which is a real shame as the 2v2 and higher has real potential if they turned it into something that was not just a simple as a LOL like team selection at the start that has no real effect.

But let‚Äôs say they do change it to something more interesting and unique mode that separates it from the other RTS games you then run into the second problem

2) There is one competitive mode which is 1v1, so all the higher player modes don‚Äôt mean anything because if you want to be ranked there is as I said only 1v1. But as of this moment there are at a peak around 200 players for this game, which means not only is the base extremely small which will create large que times, but there are many players which I have faced that clearly have played the beta for some time which leads to HUGE disparities in game understanding and you will lose A LOT when you are trying to understand the game. 

Now for me I am fine with facing stronger opponents if makes for an interesting challenge.  The majority of players however will be completely turned off by that and with an extreme lack of AI and almost no hosted custom games you really don‚Äôt have many options.

 This brings us to the final problem

3) For a game based on history it is only appropriate to point out that past games that begin this poorly are normally abandoned. The reason is simply, this is a gaming company and no matter how passionate their developers are, if their player base is small and they can‚Äôt get it grow they will be losing money on a product. And like any other business you can‚Äôt function if you don‚Äôt get income from your products or you don‚Äôt have the reserves to fund a failing project in a hope that one day it takes off. With Age of Empires 4 and other RTS games coming not to mention games like North Guard and They are Billions that are currently out, very functional, and have a very different approach to the RTS style, it is difficult to see any other outcome than the forced abandonment of this game.

I hope I am wrong, that I can look back in weeks, months or even a year, take down my review and preach to all to go out and buy this game. But with a need for bug fixes and increase single player content , better AI, a purposefully 2v2 and higher mode, bigger player base, Inability to host private games, in game mechanical fixes with pathing, balancing, game stability, and a need for the game to make a name for its self in a different way outside of "a competitive  RTS", based on past games I can‚Äôt see a way for this game to recover and become the game I wish it could be.

author: {'steamid': '76561198022409841', 'num_games_owned': 1343, 'num_reviews': 31, 'playtime_forever': 23, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 23, 'last_played': 1522427982}
review:
Really unimpressed with this game. 

I'm a huge fan of RTS games, Age of Empires and Age of Mythology especially. While Empires Apart definitely borrows heavily from these games, it feels like a bare-bones recreation rather than something trying to build off the genre's past success.

I might be able to look past the game's poor performance, odd UI, baffling controls/hotkeys, lackluster AI, and overall lack of polish if there was something special underneath. But all that's there is a bland game which looks to appeal to RTS newcomers in the laziest way possible. There is also no meaningful single-player content, despite the game not being mechanically deep enough nor contain a sufficient amount of content to rely solely on multi-player skirmishes to carry it.

Empires Apart tries to do almost nothing new to set itself apart, and doesn't streamline the RTS genre in a satisfying enough way to be novel. I cannot in any way recommend you pick up this game, and I'm not sure if any amount of patching or future updates can fix the problems I have with it.

author: {'steamid': '76561197967419253', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 58, 'playtime_forever': 91, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 91, 'last_played': 1522410970}
review:
Doesnt do enough to set itself apart.

The devs have set themselves a pretty high bar to beat, people have been crying out for an RTS style game that brings back the good old days of AOE and this has such familiarity (even in the name) to it that you can step into the game almost immediately and find yourself back in the 90s, but this is where it makes you pause.   

It is ultimately a multiplayer game, again exactly what was offered but Im not completely sold on the idea that there is anything new here and thats my problem..  my expectations started of as 'great an AOE inspired game' and I ended up with the thought  'oh it is just AOE'... and funnily enough seen that done that.... 

I went into the skirmish mode to give myself a refresher and got smashed by the AI on medium, I know the devs have said that the AI is very efficient at managing resources but in the time I had built 3 houses, a stable and launched villagers, the ai was already sending waves of 5 or six troops to attack.. and when I did eventually get 10 units up the AI had something like 20 or 30 plus villagers.. and just blobbed, this will ultimately be the same strategy in multiplayer .

 On easy it literally did the same thing but I was able to take out its buildings in time.  Annoyingly with the AI villagers would stand around with arm full of resources and do nothing, and soldiers at times would let enemy waltz their way past without batting an eyelid, even garrisoning the villagers, all they did was to go to the building and hang around outside with their arms crossed like they were mildly cross at waiting in a toilet queue,  whilst getting lumps knocked out of them by enemy soldiers.   Scouting is painful, there is no auto scout and more often than not I completely forgot that I had sent my scout off across the other side of the map.    

Of course there is no substitute for multiplayer game play but if this is not EA and im looking at 6 factions, its quickly going to become pretty 1 dimensional.  I do hope there is no pay for DLC in this i.e adding other factions.     The fact is that he who rushes wins ... 

So if you want AOE inspired game this is it literally, its AOE, but if you were actually looking for more single player/AI this is not it... if you want AOE multiplayer then this will fill that empty hole .

author: {'steamid': '76561198311629832', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 38, 'playtime_forever': 693, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 245, 'last_played': 1526521529}
review:
As an Age of Empires II fan myself, I couldn't resist but compare this game to AOE II. I've made a well-edited video where I list all the differences I could spot. Hopefully it will give you an idea on what to expect from this game:

https://youtu.be/ZifLNfSIE4A

If you don't know AOE II, then here is a brief list of pros and cons:

- Pros:
1. Nice Graphics
2. Smooth gameplay
3. Multiplayer is alive and it takes about 7 seconds to find a ranked room
4. Lots of useful tools such as automated farm reseeding, etc
5. Six different nations, each of which features truly unique gameplay and even unique soundtracks
6. Decent balance despite the variety of units and unique abilities
7. In brief, the game looks and feels good

- Cons:
1. No campaign
2. Tutorial is short and it might be challenging for a newcomer to learn all of the things they need to be good at the game
3. Requires quite a beefy PC (will NOT work on a PC/laptop without a dedicated GPU)
4. Just like in AOE II and most RTS games, multiplayer latency depends on the host. There are no dedicated game servers, which is not an issue usually, though sometimes it can get a bit challenging to deal with the lag

In brief:
Would I recommend you this game? If you are an AOE II fan, then sure. It is totally worth a try. I wouldn't recommend you this if you are totally new to RTS because it's quite challenging for now. Otherwise, it's a decent game and I'd say, if you've got the money, give it a try.

author: {'steamid': '76561198051229051', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 1914, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 881, 'last_played': 1563300283}
review:
good rts game with new stuff like more diffrent civs and instead of ages your have two branches to evolve where you can decide if you focus more on military (for a a rush for example) or economy. Civs like the mongols and their normad style is pretty nice handled, also like the variety and things like the challenges. If you like rts you will have your fun. I wouldn¬¥t say its here to replaces games like aoe2hd but you should rather see it as 2 rts, which you can have your fun it. It has some starting bugs and multiplay has sometimes some problems but Game ist just released and it is definitly playable and I believe devs will work hard to fix these issues, it¬¥s nothing gamebreaking and can be resolved.
You can defnitly give it a try

author: {'steamid': '76561198065664411', 'num_games_owned': 36, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 150, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 150, 'last_played': 1522400834}
review:
We should not forget that RTS fans have high standards. Not only do they want a fantastic singleplay campaign, they also want a "perfect" balance in multiplay. But both don't matter much to me. Campaigns are not so important to me because I play RTS mainly in multiplay. At the same time, I also understand that it is almost impossible to have a "perfect" balance in multiplay.

So why am I going to give this game the thumbs-down? I just wanted something basic. The UI of this game is bizarre. You can't set a rally point to animals to gather food. It's possible to automine any other resources such like gold, stone, tree by setting a rally point, but You can't set a rally point to animals including livestock like sheeps. Why is it impossible to automine food only while other resources may be able to be automined? That's pretty inconsistant.

One more thing about the UI. When you place a mouse cursor over a unit's icons, it is expected to see their meanings. For example, when you select a Chinese Qingqibing(it's a light cavalry unit of China faction) and place a mouse cursor over its icons, you may assume somehow that "the axe 4" is its attack value, "the shoes 360" are its speed value though there aren't any explanations. But it is pretty hard to assume the difference between "the normal shield 0" and "the broken shield 2". I know there is the saddle icon explaining "Vulnerable to Long Weapon", but it's not enough. They really need to add more explanations.

As a RTS fan, I really wanted to give this game the thumbs-up. It is not easy to create RTS in today's age. Therefore, the developer's courage is worthy of praise. But they failed even to meet my low standard, just a normal UI.

author: {'steamid': '76561197997782035', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 845, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 488, 'last_played': 1534775536}
review:
*Before reading: You want to play against a dumb NPC and always win with loads of unnenecesary clicking? This might be your game.

This game looked to be nice, nice concept good enough graphics and just the classical gameplay..

But pathfinding is a terrible mess. NPC get stuck in a loop doing nothing but spin around.
Resource depleted? Lets stand here while the next tree is only 1 block away.

besides that NPC's are also a joke. The NPC builds only houses and grabs gold like it got gold fever. Waited an hour for an NPC to start building something on hard dificulty.. Nothing else.

UI is buggy aswel. Was playing as the Mongols, and the UI start freaking out. After each 3 second it deselected everything I had selected. Byebye building or recruiting.

Considering it has been a long time in devolpment and has had a beta for quite some time with a price tag of 28 euros when not discounted.. Nope, not worth it.
Especially considering they don't release it as "early acces" but as a full release. This is far from a full release.

author: {'steamid': '76561197969893764', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 77, 'playtime_forever': 630, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 630, 'last_played': 1522530510}
review:
It has got:

singleplayer skirmish
challenges
survival mode
multiplayer
different factions
interesting mechanics

I love it. it is not AoE2 HD, but I prefer it over AoE Definitve Edition a lot.

author: {'steamid': '76561197976259471', 'num_games_owned': 2541, 'num_reviews': 183, 'playtime_forever': 77, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 77, 'last_played': 1522389493}
review: AI is pretty rough but there are very few classic style RTS games and I like that each of the factions have a distinct look. Game is a little sparse right now, like 8 maps playable as 1v1, 2v2, 3v3, or 4v4 (size wise, you can play with 2 people on an 8 person map) along with a survival mode with infinite waves. Graphics are basic but pretty good and everything has its own feel which is a good break from a lot of RTS. Recommend overall, can see the game getting to be a great strategy title.

author: {'steamid': '76561198156491504', 'num_games_owned': 132, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 4009, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 563, 'last_played': 1523219049}
review:
The game has potential. Its not much like AOE so much as in you basically just rush, all of the walls and defensive buildings in this game are useless, youll never get the chance to build them. All you do is get an army in 5 minutes and rush. 

You need a very good computer to run 4v4's on a good map. I have never had trouble running any type of game until now. 

Although my review sounds bad, this game has potential. It's not worth how much it is right now but the price might be worth it once they tweak it a bit.

review: Even warcraft 3 gettings more patches nowadays than this game, makes you think. Still desyncing (not for me but people crying all the time on discord), we were promised a decent REVOLUTIONARY AI but it doesnt even build buildings sometimes. No new content, no balancing, every good player has left the game after f2p resurgence. I cant recommnd you to invest time into this, maybe an occasional fun-game with friends, but this is not for-fun game since its very tryhardish in its nature.

author: {'steamid': '76561198016687009', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 2155, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1186, 'last_played': 1523845799}

+ÏïÑÎûçÏùÄ Í≥ºÌïôÎ†•ÏúÑÏ£ºÎùºÍ≥† ÌïòÎäîÎç∞, ÏÇ¨Ïã§ ÌÅ¨Í≤å Ìã∞Îäî ÏïàÎÇ©ÎãàÎã§. ÌïòÏßÄÎßå Ï¢ÖÍµêÏù∏Í≥º Îã¨Î¶¨ ÏùòÏÇ¨Í∞Ä ÏßÄÏÜçÌûêÏùÑ Ìï¥Ï£ºÎäî Ïú†ÎãõÏúºÎ°ú  Îî∞Î°ú ÏûàÍ∏∞ ÎïåÎ¨∏Ïóê Ïó¨Îü¨Ï†ÄÎ™® ÎèÖÌäπÌï©ÎãàÎã§. ÏïÑÏ¶àÌÖçÍ≥º ÎßàÏ∞¨Í∞ÄÏßÄÎ°ú ÌååÎûÄ ÏûêÏõêÏù¥ ÏûàÎäîÎç∞, Ïù¥Í±¥ ÏãúÍ∞ÑÏù¥ ÏßÄÎÇòÎ©¥ ÏûêÎèôÏúºÎ°ú Ï±ÑÏõåÏßÄÎäîÍ±¥ÏßÄ ÌäπÏ†ï Ï°∞Í±¥Ïù¥ Î∞úÏÉùÌïòÎ©¥ Ï±ÑÏõåÏßÄÎäî Í±¥ÏßÄ Î™®Î•¥Í≤†ÏßÄÎßå, ÌïòÎã§Î≥¥Îãà Îã§ Ï±ÑÏõåÏ†∏ÏûàÏäµÎãàÎã§.

+ÏïÑÏ¶àÌÖçÏùò ÌååÎûÄ Ìù¨ÏÉù ÏûêÏõêÏùÄ  Ìè¨Î°úÎ•º Ïû°ÏùÄ Îã§Ïùå Ìï¥Îãπ Í±¥Î¨ºÏóê ÎÑ£ÏúºÎ©¥ Ïä§ÌÉùÏù¥ ÏåìÏó¨ÏÑú ÏÇ¨Ïö©Ïù¥ Í∞ÄÎä•Ìï©ÎãàÎã§.
Ïù¥Î•º ÌÜµÌï¥ÏÑú ÏïÑÏ¶àÌÖçÏùÄ Íπ° Î≥¥Î≥ëÏùò ÌîºÌÜµÍ≥º Í≥µÏÜç, Í≥µÏÑ±Ïù¥ Ï∂îÍ∞Ä ÏûêÏõêÏóÜÏù¥ Ï¶âÌö®ÏÑ±ÏúºÎ°ú ÏóÖÍ∑∏Î†àÏù¥Îìú Í∞ÄÎä•Ìï®ÏúºÎ°ú, Ï¥àÎ∞òÏóê Ïú†ÏùºÌïòÍ≤å Î≥¥Î≥ëÏù¥ ÏãùÎüâÎßå Î®πÎäî Ïù¥Ï†êÏùÑ Ïù¥Ïö©Ìï¥ÏÑú Î¨ºÎüâÏúºÎ°ú Î≥¥ÎÇ¥ÏÑú Ìè¨Î°úÎ•º Îã§Ïàò ÌôïÎ≥¥ÌïòÎäî Í≤ÉÏù¥ Ìè¨Ïù∏Ìä∏ÏûÖÎãàÎã§. author: {'steamid': '76561197966405995', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 1337, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 85, 'last_played': 1584825767}
review: a fantastic rts

author: {'steamid': '76561198085228465', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 453, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 453, 'last_played': 1522371596}
review:
I have been playing AoE2 and saw this game.

Very buggy AI, on Survival mode I was able to trick AI into simply walking back and forth and never attack due to pathfinding. Villagers also frequently get stuck on objects.
Love the graphics and style and the UI is ok.


Overall I still prefer AoE2.

author: {'steamid': '76561198023087728', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 55, 'playtime_forever': 289, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 270, 'last_played': 1522877977}
review: va lento el juego no se porque !!! tengo un ordenador nuevo y potencial ... no se porque !! el unico juego va lento !!

author: {'steamid': '76561198128359543', 'num_games_owned': 237, 'num_reviews': 98, 'playtime_forever': 130, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 94, 'last_played': 1544137090}
review:
This is a complete game with minimum feature, not as people said it's incomplete. 
And even though A.I. is really not as good as other RTS but still better than Civ 6 if you ask me.

The graphic and music are medicore, the concpet of art was nice though.

The only problem I have with this game is that I cannot escape from the horrible FPS drop no matter how I tune down the setting.

And with i7 6700 and GTX 1080 I'm pretty sure the problem is not on my end...

I'll refund for now, I'll purchase it again once this lag and fps issue is fixed.

author: {'steamid': '76561198030997975', 'num_games_owned': 511, 'num_reviews': 42, 'playtime_forever': 65, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 65, 'last_played': 1522367685}
review:
Nice game
lacks a campaing tho

author: {'steamid': '76561198079069915', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 326, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 305, 'last_played': 1522661096}
review:
To keep it short this is an excellent multiplayer RTS game inspired by AoE (Age of Empires) but innovating at the same time.

The one major short-coming is the lack of singleplayer (the AI is not great and really only seems to prepare you for multiplayer) so if that is what you were looking for I am afraid you should look at other games, such as AoE, Grey Goo or the upcoming Iron Harvest.

author: {'steamid': '76561198071894016', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 586, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 185, 'last_played': 1546432056}
review:
Would have recommended if it had the "Early access" tag.
It doesn't.

The game simply isn't finished.
- AI is really poor.
- pathing is cluncky
- resources are scarce and easily run out (especially on island maps.)
- town center f.e. can't give command to spawning villagers to gather meat from sheep/deer.
- commands to other resources often don't work properly either as the units get stuck on the way
- maps are very basic and uninteresting.
- the game itself is ... basicly AOE (obviously) but once you get ingame.
And you see the buildings / upgrades / resource costs / styles and interactions.
you'll realise how much this is a copy/paste of aoe with barely any new or "modern" spin to it.
in fact it either lacks things wich even "AOE the rise of rome"  had or does a worse job at it.
- optimisation ? have to run it on medium and close my "Black Desert Online" to prevent lag.
for comparison: i ran farcry 5 on max settings yesterday while running black desert in the background without an issue
- and yes after closing everything but the game. putting it on medium settings... it just crashed on me several times.

Sigh. don't feel like making the list longer than it is.
I've been trying to get into the beta for this game a long time.
Been eagerly waiting for the release.
But this.
Is sad :c

I will edit this review once they've added some patches*
So far this was my first impression.

author: {'steamid': '76561197977723316', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 77, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 77, 'last_played': 1522360741}
review:
Overall the game lacks a lot of polish and finish. AI is terrible and spent whole game making useless buildings which it deleted randomly later on. I am currently requesting a refund. 

Some may find enjoyment with this as it is almost a reskin of Age of Empires II (so similar I am surprised they are not in trouble for blatent copying). This Despite the updated graphics, combat has very basic animations and the game is not enjoyable to look at. I am fine with the overall look of the game, but I am saying some parts and animations just do not look finished. 

Overall, I was excited and the gameplay can be enjoyable, but the game overall seems unfinished and needs some work

author: {'steamid': '76561198031890854', 'num_games_owned': 441, 'num_reviews': 33, 'playtime_forever': 41, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 41, 'last_played': 1522356760}
review:
Followed the game for a year or so, I was expecting the AI to be better than the 1999 Age of Empires AI. The AI kept standing still doing nothing, destroying buildings and rebuilding them, and others weren't even trying to compete over relics nor were some even attacking me. (And this was on hardest.)

As usual in this time of day: Graphics are awesome, gameplay not so much. 

What should've been an awesome launch resulted in me refunding the game in it's current state. Feels like a shame as I hoped to it to launch (as the teaser told) 'a new age of genre'.

EDIT: I did want to add to my fairly negative review that I was just hoping the developers would've pushed out a stable version of the game, and not in early beta stage. AI bugs this bad could've been avoided more easy than people think.

I don't accept that kind of developer behaviour, and neither shouldn't you.

author: {'steamid': '76561198021695834', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 29, 'playtime_forever': 1162, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 495, 'last_played': 1573951461}

author: {'steamid': '76561198239512330', 'num_games_owned': 31, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 6983, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1364, 'last_played': 1541536709}
review:
I played 12 games so far and enyoed the game a lot. 

It feels like a fresh mix of Command & Conquer and Age of Empires, is very fast, skill testing and has 6 very different civilizations. The balance is obviously not perfect yet and the art style takes some getting used to but is not that important to me.

Overall I can recommend it to every real time strategy fan looking for something new.

author: {'steamid': '76561198099589436', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 14668, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 13042, 'last_played': 1544643121}
review:
After playing this game for almost 200 hours (Beta participant I can say the game has potential but it just has many flaws. There is no singleplayer campaign and the AI is very weak even on "hardest". The few single player challenges can be completed within 2 hours MAX if you are new to the game. 

The night in the day-night cycle is too dark. The civs are unbalanced. Some civs lack depth and so you are stuck with the same strategy over and over again. No replays available. No scenario editor. You cannot set way points of your towncenter on sheep or other living resources. Sometimes it is very hard to differentiate buildings (arab house / arab storage) and the units throughout all civs. And many other stuff that is just annoying...

The focus is clearly on Multiplayer 1 vs 1. You can get a ranked match real fast if you click on"duel". But you cannot see who your opponent is (Steam-name) and what civ he picked until you are in the game.

If you are into a broken 1 vs 1 multiplayer fun game it is ok for you. Otherwise I would suggest waiting for another game or stick to aoe2...

author: {'steamid': '76561198055780740', 'num_games_owned': 5600, 'num_reviews': 148, 'playtime_forever': 2568, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2568, 'last_played': 1522352550}
review:
[h1]Overview[/h1]
Empires Apart is an RTS that barely gets a recommended. It is heavily inspired by Age of Empires in all the right ways, but lacks a singleplayer campaign. Without a campaign, this game is hard to recommend for its $30 price point. As for gameplay, research has been streamlined to increase the speed at which a game is played. Races are also incredibly unique, the most of any RTS I‚Äôve played. Graphics are polygonal and sharp while staying slightly abstract. The sound design is good and every race has unique voice lines for their units. The music is orchestral and war like to hype up the player. The netcode really impressed me. I played against another player in Germany and there wasn‚Äôt any noticeable lag present. 

[h1]Game Breakdown[/h1]
[u]Gameplay:[/u]
The gameplay is typical for the RTS genre. The player must collect four different resources with peasants. These include food, gold, stone, and lumber. Lumber is key to the construction of buildings and is an important early game resource. Food is good all game as it is used to recruit units such as peasants and military units. Stone is mainly used for late game defensive structures and gold is used to buy resources and construct military units. This isn‚Äôt the case for every races as Aztecs only need food for their first military unit.

The six different races in Empires Apart are some of the most unique races I have ever played in an RTS. Every race a completely different set of mechanics for its units. For example, Aztec units gain experience while fighting which allows them to level up into a new, more powerful, form. They don‚Äôt however have any upgrades to replace the weak early game units with stronger late game units. While they do have some late game options, their mechanics require a player using the Aztecs to be constantly battling and improving their troops. This plays into the Aztec priests as they are able to heal one‚Äôs units.  To get better units for most races requires research.

The research system in this game is greatly simplified. Instead of requiring a certain amount of buildings or previous research, two types of research are available from the beginning. These are economic research and military research. Economic research allows the player to build economic research centers, and occasionally unique buildings such as Arabian universities, that provide resource collection buff to peasants. Military research in turn provides new military buildings, unit upgrades and defensive options, like stone walls, to the player‚Äôs build menus. By simplifying the research and making it available from the beginning, games are much faster and only take about 20 to 25 minutes each. Besides battling with typical military units, heroes are also added to the mix. 

Heroes are extremely late game units that can turn the tide of the gmae. Each race has both a warrior hero who participates in battle, and a ruler hero, who gives buildings and workers various bonuses. Some of the warriors have an aura such as the Mongols Chinggis Khaan who empowers the bloodlust abilities of his units. Other warriors have active abilities that can change the tide of a battle. For example, Jean d‚ÄôArc can create a protective bubble around an area which protects friendly units from ranged unit fire. The rulers give strong buffs on the player‚Äôs settlements which can range from worker buffs to Acamapichtili‚Äôs ability to instantly finish buildings.

One of the major disappointments of this game is that it lacks any long term singleplayer content. Skirmishes are included and the AI is decent. A survival mode is included where the player has to defeat increasingly difficult waves of enemies. Finally, challenges are short and frustrating distractions that often rely on using concepts such as kiting to complete them. There is unfortunately no campaign available for this game at the time of writing which is a huge waste of potential. One of the most memorable parts of games such as Age of Empires, Empire Earth, etc. is their enjoyable campaigns. 

Overall, this is an enjoyable RTS with a large focus on the competitive multiplayer scene. Matches are fast paced and the variety of races make every match-up feel fresh. Without a good campaign, Empires Apart can‚Äôt be one of the greats of the RTS genre.

[u]Sound:[/u]
Sound design is quite good. Each race has its own voice lines for each unit. Each unit has only a few voice lines and every time the player right clicks it plays one. I would have preferred a short delay before the next line is played. The ambience is quite nice and so is the music. The music is also unique for each race which improves the uniqueness of each race. The songs are rallying and war like, even the title screen music. 

 [u]Graphics:[/u]
The graphics are an abstract polygonal style that works quite well with this game. Even though they are a bit abstract, units are unique and can be easily distinguished in a large scale battle. The same goes for heroes. Buildings fall apart in chunks which are acted upon by physics and makes destroying enemy buildings all the more satisfying. 
 
[u]Performance:[/u]
The netcode for this game is astonishingly good. I have played against another player in Germany while I‚Äôm on the US east coast, and there wasn‚Äôt any noticeable lag at all. This is great considering players who pick up this game will be spending most of their time in multiplayer.

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]
[u]Pros:[/u]
Unique Races
Solid RTS Gameplay
Great Netcode
Fast Matches

[u]Cons:[/u]
Lack of Meaningful Singleplayer Content
High Price for Amount of Content

[u]Rating[/u]
[b]7/10[/b].

If you liked this review or want to see more recommended games, be sure to follow our curator group: [url=http://steamcommunity.com/groups/Original_Curators_Group#curation]Follow Original Curator Group[/url]

author: {'steamid': '76561198107996703', 'num_games_owned': 561, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 15365, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 13966, 'last_played': 1544802921}
review:
Need to write a new review now that this game was made free to play. Here's the old review when the game was first released:

Short version.
I like the game. Can recommend.

Long version:
I come from AoE2 background (around 600h playtime). I can't compare this to other RTS like StarCraft 2 but I can give an AoE2 player's perspective on this. I have played around 120h in the Empires Apart's beta.

If you have played AoE 2 you can pick up the basics fast. This game isn't a simple AoE2 clone. The game has its own feel to it and differentiates from AoE2 in many aspects. Generally the game is faster paced than AoE2 and has new mechanics and quality of life improvements.

Currently there are 6 civilizations. Every one of them is unique. For example, Mongols play completely different to the Byzantines. Each civ has some mechanics that are unique to that civ. Balancing this will be difficult but the devs are listening to the community and are ready to support the game.

There isn't a full campaign at least yet but there are puzzle-like challenges for each civ. They are great at showing the unique abilities that civs have. When you have grasped the basics of the game these are a good way to learn about unique things the civs have and some more advanced tactics.

Currently there is no scenario editor but I've heard that modding tools are going to be released sometime after the release. I'd still need a dev confirmation (maybe there's a response in the comments?) to be sure.

The game is not perfect. It currently has some bugs and balancing issues. Thankfully the devs are active and want to make this game as good as possible. They listen to the feedback and want to make the experience even better than it currently is.

I'm looking forward to seeing how this game evolves and genuinely enjoy playing it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198056687846', 'num_games_owned': 942, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 652, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 195, 'last_played': 1588440455}
review:
Although I love the concept of the game, I love the RTS genre and I love the graphics of the game... There are so many bugs that the game should not have been released as a complete game. If it was an alpha I'd understand the bugs but man the bugs are too many.

[b]- The framerate drops at a certain point in the game are unbearable. Seriously I have 2 GTX 1080s and they cannot handle this (obviously it's a bug within the game). I get 4-9 FPS in a SINGLE player game. This is advertised as MULTI player game... imagine playing a 4v4 with 6 FPS... Yeah, thought so too.

- The A.I. is pre-historic here. They do not even bother to attack me no matter the difficulty. I mean on the hardest, yes they do attack a lot more, but on normal difficulty, they come to me and just keep patrolling around, and not attacking. They only attack once I attack the units that are meant to be attacking me. Also when I build walls and block one of the ways they come, they don't try to walk around where there are no walls, they just stand there and die from the towers... Even games from the 2000s did better with A.I.

- There are so many other bugs - at first I had a problem starting the game up (that was due to Avast being a di** I suppose), then obviously the framerate... then moving to not being able to load up my saves. 

- I wish there was a campgain in this game as well, pretty much every RTS game does...[/b]

Overall, this is a very well done game, beautiful and just quite polished (in terms of gameplay and graphics), however the bugs are what just make this game unplayable, quite literally. I think with a patch or two and all of the bugs being fixed it would actually be a very good game. So yes, I would recommend to those that love the classics.

author: {'steamid': '76561198153240435', 'num_games_owned': 49, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 105, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 29, 'last_played': 1565006710}
review: I honestly don't know what to say. I am really dissapointed. I am a casual player that plays especially singleplayer, but this clearly a multiplayer game. The A.I. is extremely dumb. There is no campaign, but some really lazy "challanges". There is no editor to make our own scenarios. The singleplayer experience is non-existent. If you are for the singleplayer, this might not be the game for you. However, the graphics are really beautiful and the game runs well. The factions are truly unique and fun to play. I haven't tried the multiplayer, but I assume that it is really good. The game is really multiplayer-focused, which I guess that it's good for the community.

author: {'steamid': '76561198023666798', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 82, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 82, 'last_played': 1522350144}
review:
What a massive, massive let down this game is.
Being a huge fan of the classic RTS games for many a year, I had watched the development of this game over the last 6 or so months with interest, hoping it would pick up where the likes of AOE left off, perhaps with a modern take on the tried and trusted formats, no such luck.
Well, unless by modern, you expect the increasingly cynical approach game developers are taking these days, by releasing half finished, poorly optimised content, with the promise of further updates to provide the content that should be there at launch, this game would appear to excel in that respect.
I requested a refund after around 1 hour of play time. Having purchased around 200 games on Steam, this is only the 2nd time I've done so, here's why.
I was immediately struck by the realisation that this is nowhere near a full/finished game.
Having played through the worryingly short tutorial, and in the apparent absence of any kind of single player campaign option (really and RTS without a campaign!?) I decided I'd start off with the survival mode. 
I was astonished to find that this mode contained 1 map .... with the promise of more maps to be added later, apparently.
The map itself was beyond basic, a barren square with a few resources dotted around, and a town centre in the middle as a starting point. The idea of course, being to defend it against increasingly difficult waves of enemies, something I became bored of long before the end of the 15 minutes it took the AI to overwhelm my increasingly half hearted attempts at defence.
I decided next, to give the challenge scenarios a bash, hoping that it would form the basis of some kind of campaign to play through, no such luck, just very basic scenarios of units squaring off against one another ... 2 archers vs a more powerful infantry unit, etc,etc ... again I became very bored, very quickly and gave up after a few of these challenges.
So then, nothing else for it, with little interest in playing multiplayer, at least until I'd managed to get a few practice games under my belt, I gave the skirmish a go.
Again, an absolute dearth of options here. The basic, choose AI opponent, choose difficulty, and if you like, set teams, and with only 7 maps, little scope for variety.
Having set up a skirmish against 2 AI opponents on a large island map, I clicked on start ... and the game promplty crashed, kicking me back out to desktop.
Another failed attmpt at launching a skirmish, was more than enough to put my already rapidly waning interest in this game to bed.
Perhaps someone with a little more perseverance, would have messed around with their settings enough to get the skirmish mode working, however having already tired of this mess of a game, I seen little point in wasting more of my time trying to get this poorly optimized, half hearted, half finished game, to run.
Becoming increasingly sick of being conned out of my money by developers who can't be bothered to finish their games before releasing them, I decided I wanted a refund, and I also decided to take the time to write this review (again something I very rarely do) in the hope that it would save someone else the disappointment of playing this game.
Do yourself a favour, go back to AOE, dust of your copy of C&C, or content yourself with another go around on Sins of a Solar Empire, in the hope that at some point, someone, somewhere, will do this classic genre some justice again.

author: {'steamid': '76561198044754679', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 33, 'playtime_forever': 21, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 21, 'last_played': 1522352688}
review:
Yes, I am giving a thumbs down after playing this game for less than an hour. I think the game is relatively fun, but it feels like a blatant copypasta of Age of Empires II. This isn't really a bad thing, but I'm not ready to throw $30 (at full price) for this game when I can go play the original. 

I think the developers did a decent job with it, but I'm just not sold on it so I asked for a refund. It just feels way too similar despite a couple differences. I'd love to revisit it should it go on a deeper sale.

author: {'steamid': '76561198070524658', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 79, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 79, 'last_played': 1522351156}
review: The challenges are fun however that's almost all I can play as it lags a lot for me if I try to play any map size other than the small 1v1 map. Hopefully this gets fixed as it seems like a really good game otherwise.
developer_response:
Hi Lorne Malvo,

Unfortunately some people had low framerate issues at launch, but yesterday we released a patch which should fix the issue.

Would you consider giving a second try to the game and, if you like what you see, reconsidering your review? :)

author: {'steamid': '76561198408128812', 'num_games_owned': 35, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 307, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 289, 'last_played': 1522766247}
review: The gameplay is really good but sucks big time. I played with 7 others 2v2v2v2 my fps dropped from beign 60-80 in a 1v1 to 20. The ms was so high that the delay was 3 seconds. I recommend this game once they have fixed the multiplayer. The server is really shit. 1v1 is super optimal tho.

author: {'steamid': '76561198005974950', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 6669, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6357, 'last_played': 1575374475}
review:
The best RTS game in a LONG time. 

There are problems obviously, with balance and a few bugs, but they will be fixed in time and over all the multiplayer experiance is super enjoyable and pretty smooth.

Considering that this is a game made by 3 develoupers for the most part I believe it is an incredible success! Some AI behvaiours and a few odd decisions aside the game is super complex and really enjoyable. 

Pro tip tho, turn motion blur off, many people have been saying that scrolling is laggy and it's a misconception due to motion blur so turn it off and you'll have no problems! 

GLHF!

author: {'steamid': '76561198029802694', 'num_games_owned': 543, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 3999, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2864, 'last_played': 1574801787}
review:
Seguo Empires Apart da tempo ed ho avuto anche il piacere di essere scelto per la beta.

Progetto italiano molto ambizioso che sta rispettando ci√≤ che mi aspettavo e per questo non posso che consigliarlo.

Al prezzo di un indie (essendo uno di essi), potrete divertirvi con un RTS old-school che mischia diversi concetti in un unico gioco.

Se vi piace Age of Empires, Age of Mithology o Warcraft, questo gioco far√† per voi.

author: {'steamid': '76561198076870284', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 15206, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 12235, 'last_played': 1628346370}
review:
Empires Apart review from a multilayer rts player.

First of all I want to say I have been close to the developer process since the alpha and have seen and amazing progress. The developers have showed great work ethic and have been really upfront with the testers. If you don't want to read the full review the tl;dr is game is still not perfect but is made by great and passionate people and based on my 2 year involvement in the game I am sure they will continue improving Empires Apart and iron the small flaws it has. In my current personal ranking Empires Apart is the most fun rts on the market and 2nd best all around after Starcraft 2.

Game play: The game has six unique civilization with completely different playstyles. The balance is still not there but the multilayer is still extremely fun and I know people with 1000 hours just in the beta playing multilayer vs the AI or the same opponent just because they got addicted to the game. 

Features: The multilayer rts players will be extremely pleased to hear that the game has really good pathfinding and all the important features a modern rts game should have I,  including unit grid, shift queue, control click, ranked system with mmr,  leaderboards and many more. There are still some issues but I am sure the game will get improved along the way knowing the passion the developers have for this game.

Community: The people I met in the alpha/beta are probably the best community I have been part of. Furthermore the game has attracted a lot of high level and pro players from other rts games which has made even the early testing phase of the game really competitive.

Important to note is that some stuff like replays didn't make it to the release version of the game but the development of a indie game with limited resources and tiny team has to face the dead line at some point and I have been assured that replays and many other features are coming ! All those are more quality of life improvements and there is nothing missing from the game that can stop you from having either casual fun or play high level matches against great players.

author: {'steamid': '76561198001561071', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 2630, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2235, 'last_played': 1540195481}
review:
I update my Review.
Now i will recommand this game to anyone ;)
The thing is, on launch 1 week ago, it was not really playable for alot of people's.
Including me, There was a critical error or so with some AMD CPU's.

BUT developer manage to fix this yesterday.
THe performance get a really good boost, and its now playable for me!

Nice patch from the dev's and this in 1 week? very nice.

So now this game has good hotkey settings, smooth gameplay, and a Ladder.
I am happy ;)
Also i guess the dev's will update frequently  in terms of balance and small improvements about the pathing and so.

Still its allready a really cool game.

author: {'steamid': '76561197988918545', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 69, 'playtime_forever': 828, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 343, 'last_played': 1679514106}
review:
Ich finde das Spiel Cool :)

Es ist anders als das Originale Age of Empires. 

Aufgefallene √§nderungen z.B mehrere Civiliationen die unterschiedliche m√∂glichkeiten haben. Wie z.B Nomaden Da gibt es wie bei den Wikingern (Age of Mytholgoy) Einheiten die Bauen k√∂nnen und Siedler.

Oder anstatt im Dorfentrum ins n√§chste Zeitalter zu steigen gibt es Wirtschaftliche oder Milit√§rische  Weiterentwicklung. Die man im Obern mittleren Bildschirmrand anklicken kann. 

Wirtschaftlich = > Weiterentwicklungen f√ºr Wirtschaft
Milit√§risch => Neue Soldaten + Milit√§rische upgrades usw...

Ich finde im gro√üen und ganzen das Spiel gut gelungen. Ich werde es weiterhin spielen :-) 
Die grafik ist bissl gew√∂hnungsbed√ºrftig aber sonst sehr gut.

Was ich Negativ finde. Es gibt irgendwie kaum Spieler in der Lobby :(. Kaum Games offen bei Release vielleicht √§ndert sich das noch.

author: {'steamid': '76561198037149488', 'num_games_owned': 225, 'num_reviews': 29, 'playtime_forever': 4587, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1126, 'last_played': 1539723001}
review:
Empezar√© por partes, esto es lo que todos los fans de el age of empires 2 andaban buscando, un juego muy bien hecho pero adem√°s con el puntazo de que hace un gran honor al AOE 2 sin ser un clon.

Tenemos 6 civilizaciones divididas en subgrupos por as√≠ decirlo de la siguiente manera:
Bizantinos y Franceses---> Expansi√≥n.
Chinos y √Årabes--->Protecci√≥n.
Aztecas y Mongoles--->Agresi√≥n.

Cada civilizaci√≥n tiene una forma distinta de juego basada en su estilo, expansi√≥n, protecci√≥n y agresi√≥n.. siendo como bien se deduce mas agresivas o mas defensivas en plan tanke.

Las diferencias entre la forma de jugar es tal que por ejemplo los mongoles (civilizaci√≥n n√≥mada), sus unidades son las que se convierten en los edificios estilo zergs del starcraft con la peculiaridad de que puedes recuperar al aldeano si desmontas la construcci√≥n.

De verdad que se agradece esto, es decir.. no tenemos 15 civilizaciones o m√°s practicamente iguales entre ellas, si no que tenemos 6 diferenciadas en subgrupos y con un estilo de juego muy diferente entre ellas.

En cuanto a la configuraci√≥n del teclado es otra maravilla, tenemos la capacidad de crearnos el perfil para cada civilizaci√≥n y elegir nuestras macros (accesos directos con las teclas), etc.
Cabe destacar que antes de empezar una partida con la civilizaci√≥n podemos elegir un heroe entre 2 que nos da a elegir con ciertas habilidades √∫nicas.

Otra cosa distinta al age of empires es que aqu√≠ no se avanza de edad si no que tenemos dos ramas en las que ir avanzando, o avanzamos en ec√≥nom√≠a (mejorando as√≠ los aldeanos, edificios ec√≥nomicos etc), o avanzamos en t√©cnolog√≠a militar en la que mejoramos directamente las unidades militares a costa de una econom√≠a peor pero con una capacidad ofensiva mayor, todo depende de la civilizaci√≥n y el estilo de juego que escojamos.

Podemos avanzar por ejemplo primero en econom√≠a y a continuaci√≥n avanzar en militar, el comienzo es simple ya que no se nos mezclan los recursos, para avanzar en econom√≠a son por ejemplo 400 de madera, y en militar 400 de comida, pero deberemos elegir en que avanzar primero.

Por cada vez que avancemos en econom√≠a por ejemplo podremos crear un centro urbano adicional.

Luego otra de las diferencias que hay es en las reliquias y en los monjes, una funci√≥n muy similar al age of empires pero tambi√©n con diferencia bastante grande entre ellos, por ejemplo... Los monjes chinos tienen un da√±o bastante interesante dando mamporros a lo m√°s t√≠pico shaol√≠n eso s√≠ no pueden transformar a las unidades enemigas, y si los dejas quietos pasados unos segundos entrar√°n en posici√≥n de meditaci√≥n y curar√°n autom√°ticamente a las unidades de alrededor dentro de un area.

Hay una estrat√©gia un tanto curiosa de los chinos, y es que no tienen mejoras para recoger m√°s rapidamente la madera, o el oro como otras civilizaciones pero tienen una opci√≥n que podemos activar o desactivar a nuestro antojo en la que recogen los recursos m√°s r√°pidamente a costa de que el aldeano va perdiendo vida progresivamente hasta llegar al punto de morir, si en lugar de ello ponemos cerca alg√∫n monje que cura en area y los posicionamos de forma que los aldeanos est√©n dentro de su area de sanaci√≥n podremos combar las dos cosas.

Recoger√°n recursos m√°s r√°pidamente y no morir√° ning√∫n aldeano, curiosa forma de llenarte la ciudad de monjes.

Las reliquias pueden ser transportadas al templo, igual que en el age of empires 1 y 2 pero... dan unas ventajas muy buenas en la partida haciendo muy interesante su recogida, por no decir que casi obligatoria.

Conforme vamos reuniendo reliquias recibiremos distintas bonificaciones para la civilizaci√≥n, obteniendo al reuniras + 1 de ataque + 1 de defensa para TODAS las unidades, +1 de oro por segundo, +1 de alcance para las unidades a distancia, y as√≠... contra m√°s reliquias obtengamos mejores bonificaciones obtendremos para la civilizaci√≥n.

Por decir algo que para mi no es negativo pero que para algunas personas puede que lo sea,  [b] no tiene modo campa√±a, est√° completamente enfocado al multijugador, la IA deja mucho que desear en las partidas tambi√©n  tiene un modo de juego llamado supervivencia en el que recoges recursos durante el d√≠a y por la noche te atacan, debes sobrevivir el m√°ximo tiempo posible.

Para los amantes de los RTS que busquen partidas multijugador, clasificatorias etc y un sucesor m√°s que digno para el AOE 2, este es tu juego, [B]  si por el contrario buscas una campa√±a y dem√°s, no lo compres porque no tiene.  [/b]

La banda sonora es de lo mejorcito, tenemos cantidad de mapas diferentes en las que se va alternando d√≠a y noche conforme jugamos un detalle m√°s a√±adido.

[b]
[h1]
[u]
Pros:
[/u]

-Civilizaciones muy diferenciadas entre s√≠.

-Interfaz muy intuitiva y fluida.

-Gran capacidad para macrear las teclas de forma comoda y diferente para cada civilizaci√≥n con la creaci√≥n sencilla de perfiles para el teclado.

-Muy enfocado a multijugador, est√° en pre-season con lo cual hay clasificaciones seg√∫n el nivel que tengamos, lo t√≠pico, oro, plata, platino etc...

-Muy buena banda sonora, cada civilizaci√≥n tiene su propia m√∫sica.

-Ciclo de d√≠a y noche, el rango de visibilidad por la noche se ver√° bastante reducida, (ciertas unidades tienen ventajas √∫nicas de noche, como los asesinos) un punto que a simple vista parece simple pero que es bastante importante.
[u]
Contras:
[/u]

-No tiene campa√±a (es una l√°stima ya que con los heroes habr√≠a quedado muy bien un modo historia, ojal√° la implementen m√°s adelante.)

-Tiene algunos peque√±os bugs en el path finding al clickar y que las unidades tomen un camino erroneo o equivocado para llegar, (no he tenido casos graves ni desastrosos, ni me ha pasado frecuentemente como en el age of empires definitive edition, pero si me ha pasado alguna vez, nada grave y que supongo que solventaran en pr√≥ximos parches.)

-En ocasiones se cierra el juego al terminar la partida, es un error un poco molesto que supongo que arreglar√°n en alg√∫n hotfix.

-La IA tiene unos errores bastante gordos que deber√≠an de arreglar cuanto antes, muy poca dificultad y movimientos sin sentido en las partidas.

[/h1]

[B]  En mi opini√≥n personal basandome siempre en el aspecto multijugador, es un juego muy bueno 9 de 10.

[/B]
[/B]
[/B]

Tened en cuenta que mi valoraci√≥n es  siempre enfoc√°ndola en el apartado multijugador que es lo que m√°s me interesa, he pasado por alto los notables bugs de la IA y la falta de campa√±a, aspectos basados en el modo un jugador.  

No he tenido lag en ninguna partida, ni problemas de desconexi√≥n, de momento.
Repito, conforme est√° el juego ahora si tu intenci√≥n es jugar vs la ia en partidas de un jugador, no lo compres porque te defraudaras.

Si por el contrario te interesa jugar en multijugador competitivo con clasificaciones y dem√°s y te gustan los RTS puede ser una compra muy interesante.

author: {'steamid': '76561198374682041', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 803, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 51, 'last_played': 1524495024}
