author: {'steamid': '76561198076395663', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 705, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 561, 'last_played': 1523745199}
review:
Great game if you're into AoE2, PVP especially, but also if you're into RTS games in general. However it's not "basically Age of Empires". The basic eco at the start is the same (luring boars etc.) but afterwards the differences really show.

What I like especially is how different the civs are. It's not just differently skinned units, some unique units, some bonuses and some locked techs; the civs are REALLY different. 

Game isn't that expensive so give it a try maybe, would be sad to see another great RTS die of a lack of players. There are problems but I rather give it a try and hope the issues get fixed than miss out on this!

author: {'steamid': '76561198116201086', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 35, 'playtime_forever': 623, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 515, 'last_played': 1523053122}
review:
I don't get why so many people are downvoting this game after 1 or 2 hours playing it.
This is an RTS man! Wait AT LEAST 10 hours of game, then write the review...
I followed all the development of this game, since 2016. I couldn't wait to play it and I'm not disappointed at all. This game is just so cool and the meta with 6 very different civs feels great. Give it a chance, a real one.

author: {'steamid': '76561198002164043', 'num_games_owned': 85, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 2181, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 871, 'last_played': 1563197196}
review:
A formula we all know and love, collect resources, build a town, build an army and attack, however empires apart has its own identity with some smart game mechanics such as hero units, night and day cycle, and very different unique factions, the factions are so individual with unique buildings, tech trees and units. 

The only thing missing is a good single player campaign mode, it does have ai skirmish options, but as of this review the ai does need a little extra work. The devs are aware of both problems and have promised free updates and dlc support for the foreseeable future. 

If you like RTS games this is a must buy

author: {'steamid': '76561197966440133', 'num_games_owned': 186, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 1317, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 847, 'last_played': 1548002852}
review:
I've been following this game for more then a year now and it is finally released! The dev team is great and really listens to the community feedback. Granted it is only a small team, it is quite remarkable what they've accomplished so far.

Although I am not really into 'Age of' games in general, i do love this game! So even if you are coming from a CNC or BFME background like me, give this one a try. I am sure you won't regret it!

review: At first sight it looked like a decent game. I can run any game on Ultra quality, but when i explore a map, even a small one and with some units in it, i realised its really poorly optimized. When im scrolling trough the map its nothing but lagg and lagg and lagg. ruins the fun for me, it should be a game that runs smooth. I cant recommend the game right now.

author: {'steamid': '76561198002039805', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 178, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 135, 'last_played': 1504227322}
review:
Empires Apart succeeds as a small, tightly-designed and multiplayer-focused successor to traditional RTS games like AoE2. Playing this really hits the nostalgia feels - the initial moments of gameplay feel very similar to AoE 2, with a Town Center, villagers who can gather resources, and a single scout to start exploring the map. However, once you start creating more buildings and researching new technologies, the game opens out to be something quite unique. Each civilisation has their own buildings, units, technology tree and special abilities that differentiate them far more than other games.  The way that Byzantines play compared to the Aztecs or Mongols is pronounced, and it stops the game from becoming too repetitive where you just play the same tactics over and over. The addition of one-off "Hero" units with special abilities adds some interesting variation into the game as well, forcing you to learn to micro your units instead of just sending your entire army into battle and leaving them to it. Players of traditional RTS games will probably enjoy the way that you can play skirmish against the A.I and just base build, hop into a multiplayer lobby to play with randoms or friends, or join the Ranked Duel queue for more intense matches against other players.

There are a couple of absent features, such as a campaign or map editor, which is unfortunate but understandable given that this is an indie game from a small team. On the plus side, the devs have confirmed that modding tools will be coming later, and depending on the success of the game maybe even a campaign will be added. In terms of how it plays, there are some oddities and bugs - unit pathing is usually fine but occasionally bugs out, and if you play against someone with a dodgy internet connection then rejoining the game can be a little hit or miss - but for the most part, it's a pretty stable game.

Overall I really like it. It's a more modern, interesting take on the same principles that make AoE great. So long as you can accept that it's more focused around multiplayer or A.I skirmish modes, I would say that it is well worth getting.

author: {'steamid': '76561198061661794', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 50, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 50, 'last_played': 1522381764}

author: {'steamid': '76561197988636447', 'num_games_owned': 655, 'num_reviews': 35, 'playtime_forever': 217, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 69, 'last_played': 1540600752}
review:
Ah, finally an RTS in the style of AoE or Rise of Nations again.

And the (few) civilizations that are in the game are different enough. 

There are still some bugs (e.g. one of my riders in the Byzantine faction was goofing around when it stood between 2 buildings) and the AI isn't the best yet (was building houses in my city when I nearly destroyed it). Don't get me wrong, the AI isn't terrible, but it needs some fixing (same goes for the animal AI).

But I really love the graphics, as they are rather unique - especially for an RTS. Oh and the music is quite good, too.

author: {'steamid': '76561197999613929', 'num_games_owned': 406, 'num_reviews': 161, 'playtime_forever': 863, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 521, 'last_played': 1524149341}
review:
Empires apart is a step into the well remembered shoes of age of empires and RTS of old, with a modern experience aimed at multiplayer gameplay.

Video:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=AYN5bbVhrBI

Text:
This is not a perfect RTS, but its pretty damn solid if you like competitive or multiplayer gameplay. the races available are diverse enough to provide tactical choice and options, while remaining coherent enough that even when you don't know every nuance you are not completely lost.

A solid chain of units, upgrades, tech advancements and tactical choices allows for diverse gameplay across the board... If you like multiplayer.

Because while the game does offer a skirmish mode (and a horde survival mode, which is fun) the AI is damned weak and provides little challenge, but the online ranked and unranked multiplayer does give the game tons of strength.

Visually the game is not a powerhouse, but the polygonal shapes of the graphics are mostly distinct and clear and while some unit details are lost in the shuffle of fighting, overall i have no complaints on the artstyle or visual fidelity.

Where i do have an issue with is the Unit AI - With pathing in particular causing me quite a few headaches when units cant decide if left or right is faster, and start spinning around in circles. Very annoying, causing unnecessary micromanagement.

Having said that, audio is also pretty solid in the title, with voice overs, music and sound queues all pretty solid.

all in all, a pretty damn enjoyable and solid multiplayer RTS experience with lots of depth and tons of fun units to play with.

If you enjoy the review [url=http://store.steampowered.com/curator/11617580/]do follow my curator feed![/url] Or check out the various other reviews on [url=https://youtube.com/c/guylogicgaming] YouTube[/url]

review:
This game is a game I'm looking for which is like age of empires II and with better connection management, graphics, interface, compatibility and others.

Also the developers showed much connectivity and supporting by listening to the players opinion to add into the game.

if this game Development stay active as we know to improve the gameplay and user experience then I recommend this game to play if u like age of empires 2.

review:

Para ser sincero Empires Apart no es un juego a la altura de los tiempos que corren. Entiendo perfectamente que son apuestas de estudios peque√±os sin un alto presupuesto, pero desde mi humilde opini√≥n y sin campa√±a NO lo recomendar√≠a.

developer_response:
Zfreny sorry you didn't enjoy the game. You are a journalist and only ever had access to a beta preview build. This is not the version that players are on now. 

Journalists are not expected to use their beta versions to write reviews on Steam! Steam reviews are supposed to be by other players on the released version, not journalists on a beta. 

Thanks for reconsidering!

author: {'steamid': '76561197966913375', 'num_games_owned': 1010, 'num_reviews': 192, 'playtime_forever': 1534, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1521, 'last_played': 1562770057}
review:
The game features a skirmish mode either online or against the AI, annoyingly unbalanced challenge scenarios (one or two friendly units against several enemies), a survival mode, and a brief tutorial. There is no campaign mode of scripted missions, though the randomized maps for the skirmish mode do give a lot of replay value. The six factions in the game are pleasingly varied. The interface has many shortcomings: resource locations need bigger indicators on the minimap, there is no ‚Äúselect all military units‚Äù button, there is no ‚Äúselect only military units‚Äù option while box-selecting, and there are no repeating or infinite queues. All of these issues become magnified with the fast pace of the game; the inefficient interface really hinders your ability to play without getting continually frustrated. Finite resources (food, wood, stone, and gold) mean migration is necessary in longer games. Efficient resource collection (by placing nearby storage structures) and continually increasing the population cap by constructing houses allow for quick upgrades to higher technology levels. Military units each have a specific counter, and while formations and stances are available, combat usually just devolves into a giant mass of units chasing a single enemy around the map. The AI can be a challenge as it is good at collecting resources and producing new villagers, but it usually sends only a few units at a time instead of a concentrated offensive. Empires Apart is a solid real-time strategy game with fast-paced gameplay and varied factions, but it lacks the smooth, feature-filled interface required for true excellence.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=bmDc-qjb7Gg
